Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Situation2: There is a plan to have a quiet ten-minute window.
Story:
I stare at the blinking cursor on my screen, the code for the core module half-finished. My phone buzzes with messages from the team: “Any update?” “We’re blocked until your part is done.” The pressure is mounting; the project manager’s voice echoes in my mind, reminding me of deadlines and dependencies. As the engineer, I know everyone is waiting on me. The build can’t move forward until I deliver.

But then, the gentle chime of my meditation app sounds. It’s time for our planned ten-minute window of mindfulness, a commitment I made to myself and my sangha. As a Buddhist, I promised to honor this space, to step away from the rush and cultivate presence. My mind is torn—one part pulled by the urgent demands of the project, the other yearning for stillness and self-compassion. My hands hover over the keyboard, heart pounding, as I wrestle with the weight of both expectations, feeling the tension coil tighter with every passing second.
